title: PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS OF GEOGRAPHIC VARIATION IN RED-TAILED CHIPMUNKS (EUTAMIAS RUFICAUDUS)
abstract: ,-Geographic variation of red-tailed chipmunks (Eu/amias ruficaudus) in the northwestern United States was studied to determine the nature of bacular variation, Bacular differences between eastern (E. r. ruficaudus) and western (E. r. simulans) forms had suggested they might be distinct species. Chipmunks from the area where the two nominal subspecies are supposedly apposed, near the border of Idaho and Montana, prove to be typical ruficaudu$, However, specimens from eastern Washington exhibit bacula that differ significantly from the typical form in seven of the eight characters studied. Discriminant function analysis unambiguously separated eastern and western bacular morphs. III another analysis, using specimens from Washington and Montana to identify "unknowns" from Idaho, each specimen from Idaho eould be allocated with confidence to one or the other reference sample. Variation in cranial morphology parallels bacular variation, but is less diagnostic. Our results corroborate the view that ruficaudus and simulans may be distinct species and repeat patterns of character variation uncovered in earlier studies of this species complex,

abstract.text: ,-Geographic variation of red-tailed chipmunks (Eu/amias ruficaudus) in the northwestern United States was studied to determine the nature of bacular variation, Bacular differences between eastern (E. r. ruficaudus) and western (E. r. simulans) forms had suggested they might be distinct species. Chipmunks from the area where the two nominal subspecies are supposedly apposed, near the border of Idaho and Montana, prove to be typical ruficaudu$, However, specimens from eastern Washington exhibit bacula that differ significantly from the typical form in seven of the eight characters studied. Discriminant function analysis unambiguously separated eastern and western bacular morphs. III another analysis, using specimens from Washington and Montana to identify "unknowns" from Idaho, each specimen from Idaho eould be allocated with confidence to one or the other reference sample. Variation in cranial morphology parallels bacular variation, but is less diagnostic. Our results corroborate the view that ruficaudus and simulans may be distinct species and repeat patterns of character variation uncovered in earlier studies of this species complex,

body_text.text: The systematics of western chipmunks (subgenus Neotamias) has long been the subject of confusion and debate. Whereas other chipmunk subgenera are monotypic, extending over continent-sized areas with slight known differentiation, Neotamias is highly polytypic, with complex patterns of distribution and variation in western North America. Some 23 species of Neotamias are currently recognized (Callahan, 1980; Hall, 1981; Patterson, 1984) , although the rank of some taxa is contested (Levenson and Hoffmann, 1984; cf. Sutton and Nadler, 1974) . Chipmunk affinities are unclear at supraspecific levels as well, with some authorities uniting all three subgenera under Tamias (Levenson et aL, 1985; Nadler et al., 1977) , whereas others (Ellis and Maxson, 1979, 1980; Hafner, 1984) maintain the traditional use of Tamias and Eutamias (including Neotamias; White 1953a). Here we follow the latter course, recognizing that the entire assemblage is in need of revision; currently, any arrangement of subgenera is contradicted by at least some characters.

Part of this confusion can be traced to anomalous patterns of cranial variation in chipmunks. Traditional cranial characters appear to be "peculiarly susceptible to environmental influences" (Merriam, 1885:28) , and thereby obscure underlying phyletic patterns (see also Allen, 1890:53; Pocock, 1923) . Chipmunk taxonomists employed a loosely defined complex of characters to delimit chipmunk species until Sutton (1953) and White (1953b) showed that otherwise poorly distinguished species could exhibit radically different bacula. Subsequent use of the baculum as a taxonomic tool has revolutionized chipmunk taxonomy: Hall and Kelson (1959) recognized only 16 species of Neotamias, while today 23 are recognized. Few other North American taxa, and none so conspicuous and diverse, can be so poorly known.

This study was undertaken to help evaluate the nature of bacular variation in chipmunks, Distinctive bacula in contiguous populations have been interpreted as evidence for reproductive isolation of chipmunks (e.g., Callahan, 1977; Patterson, 1984) . The baculum is a complex, polygenic structure which ought to vary smoothly, or at least continuously, in the absence of genetic isolation (Patterson and Thaeler, 1982) . White's (1953c) border and exhibit distinctive bacula ( Fig. 1 ) served as a starting point for thi s study. We studied geographic varia tion of Eutamia8 ruficaudu s to address whether distinctive bacula intergrade in regions of contact. We also considered how patterns of bacular variation compare with patterns of variation in other characters and the taxonomic implications of these patterns.

Field work was conducted in August and September, 1985. Collecting focused on three areas in the zone of presumed contact between ruficaudus and 6imultln.t as shown in Hall (198 1:359) : (I ) the Clea rwater Mountains (western Idaho Co., 10). whe re d istance p resum;lbly isolates sinlula lls populations from contact with ruficaudus; (2) the state bound ary (Ravalli and Missoula counties. MT and eastern Idaho Co., 10). where rufiawdus and simulans presumably contact one another; and (3) GraniteCo., MT, where rufiro.udus should be isolated from gene fl ow with sim u(ans by the valley of the West Fork of the Bitterroot. These {Xlints are plotted in Fig. 2 ns samples 6-9. Collected specimens were prepared as skins with complete skeletons (including genital bones) or preserved in fl uids and were deposited in the collections of Field Museum of Natural History (F MNH) and Museum of Zoology, University of Michigan (UMMZ).

In addition to these materials, we also examined museum specimem from the Museum of Natural History, University of Kansas (KU), and the Charles R. Conner Museum, Washington State University (WSU). Specimens were aged by tooth-wear criteria employed in earlier studies (Patterson, 1980 (Patterson, . 1984 , and only those with perma nent de ntitions at occlusal level were used in analyses of cranial morphology. Eleve n cranial measurements were t;llte n with dial calipers (to 0.1 mm). Specimens having deciduous p~$ in place C'subadul ts" of Patterson. 1980) we re used in bacular analyses. because previous work has shown that the ba culum attains ad ult dimensions relatively early (Ada ms and Sutton, 1968; Beg and Hoffmann, 1977; White. 1953b ) . Eight bacular measurements were taken on camera ludda projections from a Wild MS stereomicroscope at about 18 x using calipers and a protractor.

Because of generally smaJi sample sizes, specimens were grouped arbitrarily by county to permit statistical analyses. Computations were performed at the University of Chicago Com putation Center, using SAS parametric procedures (Ray. 1982a (Ray. , 1982b . Simple d escripti ve statistics were obtained via PROC MEANS. FTG. 2.-Distribution of red-tailed chipmunks, E. r. ruficaudus (circles) and E. r. simulans (triangles), showing geographic distribution and specimens examined. Distribution (stipple) and range limits of the two taM (dotted line) are from Hall (1981) . Squares around symbols denote type localities. Individual localities grouped into numbered samples as shown by one lines; numbers correspond to those used in tables.

Univariate analyses of variance among localities employed PROC GLM in one-way tests, ignoring sexual dimorphism because of small sample sizes. Levenson (l982) showed that female red-tailed chipmunks average about 3% larger than males in body size (actual range, -2% to 5%). Two types of discriminant function analyses were conducted. The first involved reference samples and "unknowns" to be classified (PROC DISCRIM), using geographically e)[treme individuals to identify those from intermediate localities. The second entailed multivariate analyses of variance among four groups of "knowns" and their loadings on canonical variables (PROC CANDISC).

Bacular analyses.-Means, standard deviations, and sample sizes of eight bacular characters for ten samples of red-tailed chipmunks are presented in Table L Populations identified as simulans have shorter bacula than do populations referred to ruficaudus, averaging consistently smaller in total length. Individual simulans bacula ranged from a minimum of 4.02 mm to a maximum of 4.71 mm long; ruficaudus scarcely overlapped this distribution, exhibiting bacula 4.65 mm to 5.55 rom in total length. Opposite relationships are shown by tip length and shaft bend, characters in which simulans samples are consistently larger than ruficaudus.

Results of F-tests of the equality of means are also included in Table 1 , considering variation among samples referred to first simuians, then ruficaudus, then between these groups. Only one of 16 "within taxon" tests indicate heterogeneity among samples (total length), whereas seven of eight "between taxa" comparisons differ significantly from equality. Although variation within '" <:

3.-Canonical plots of individuals of ruficaudus and simulans from discriminant function analyses of four groups: closed triangles, simulans from Washington localities (samples 1-3; Fig. 2) ; open triangles, simulans from Idaho (samples 4-5); open circles, ruficaudus from Idaho (sample 6); and closed circles, ruficaudus from Montana (samples 7-10). Upper plot shows relationships among taxa based on 11 cranial characters. Axes 1 and 2 account for 79.5% and 11% of the total dispersion, respectively. Lower plot shows relationships based on eight bacular characters. Here, axes 1 and 2 account for 98% and 1.5% of the dispersion, respectively. both taxa would be expected to increase with larger sample sizes, highly significant differences exist between Tuficaudus and simulans in spite of small samples.

Bacular data were subjected to two discriminant function analyses. The first was used to define group membership. Bacula from Washington (samples 1-3) and Montana (samples 7-10) were submitted as reference samples and used to construct linear functions distinguishing the two morphs. Discrimination of groups on the basis of bacula was complete (100% correct), and all posterior probabilities of group membership were either 1.0 or 0.0. The discriminant functions were then used to identify 23 specimens from Idaho, submitted as "unknowns." All but one unknown were allocated unequivocally (P = 0 or 1.0) to one or the other reference sample. Only a single specimen (FMNH 126119) proved somewhat intermediate, and this specimen had only a 10% probability of membership in the western group. This young adult male from sample 6 (near Lowell, ID) had a relatively short baculum (4.71 mm) with a relatively large bend to the shaft (0.82 mm), therefore deviating from typical ruficaudus in the same characters that distinguish ruficaudus and simulans. However, FMNH 126119 is not extreme in either character with respect to other individuals from this locality. FMNH 126127 was only 4.65 mm long and FMNH 126122 had a shaft bend of 0.84 mm, and both of these specimens had zero probability of membership in the western group.

A second discriminant function analysis was undertaken to relate multivariate variation within eastern and western bacular morphs to variation between them. Four "known" groups were used: the two reference samples from the previous analysis, plus the Idaho specimens referred to simulans as well as those referred to ruficaudus. A plot of individual projections along the first and second canonical axes is shown in the lower part of Fig. 3 . Eastern and western bacular morphs occupy non-overlapping segments of the first axis. Idaho specimens referred to simulans and ruficaudus overlie plots of Washington and Montana specimens, respectively, rather than lying between them, as would be expected if variation were continuous and intergradation occurred. Although the discriminant functions readily distinguished eastern and western groups, there is no significant separation between Washington and Idaho specimens of simulans or Montana and Idaho specimens of ruficaudus. These relations are summarized in comparisons of multivariate F-values (Table 2) , in which "within taxon" tests (between Idaho and Washington simulans and between Idaho and Montana ruficaudus) are not significant whereas "between taxa" comparisons are highly significant. Univariate analyses of variation for the seven characters showing significant differences between taxa revealed that differences between ruficaudus and simulans account for 16% to 77% of total variation in bacular characters.

Cranial analyses.-Means, standard deviations, and sample sizes of 11 cranial characters for 10 samples of red-tailed chipmunks are presented in Table 3 . Unlike patterns of bacular variation, the existence of discrete eastern and western morphs is not readily apparent in cranial morphology. Samples of ruficaudus average slightly larger than simulans, but even where "Between taxa" F-tests are significant, they do not explain much variation. Even statistically significant differences among the crania explain as little as 6% of the actual variation in characters such as nasal width, and differences between taxa do not account for more than 30% of the variation in any cranial character.

Weak differentiation in cranial morphology is underscored by discriminant function analysis. Discrimination of crania among the four samples defined in the second bacular analysis indicates substantial overlap among all four groups (Fig. 3) . The position of group centroids tends to reflect geographical relationships: as measured in Mahalanobis distance from the WA simulans centroid, ID simufans lies 1.55 units, ID ruficaudus 2.96 units, and MT ruficaudus 3.21 units distant. As shown in F-vaJues from this discriminant analysis (Table 2) , there are significant multivariate differences within as well as between forms identified by the bacular analysis. (Fig. 2) . Included in the table are F-tests of the equality of group means and their associated significance levels (-, P < 0.05; ."., P < 0,01; ""'""', P < 0.001; n.S., P > 0.05); numbers below significant results are R2 values from analysis of variance. "Within taxon" tests compare five populations of simuians, then five populations of ruEicaudus. "Between taxa" tests compare group means of simulans and ruficaudus. White (1953c:623) was the first to observe that ruficaudus and simulans have very different bacula, stating that their bacular differences were "comparable to those usually found between species of chipmunks." Russell and Anderson (1956) also noted the uncertain relationships between these nominal subspecies, but no additional data have been brought to bear on this question in 30 years. We have examined chipmunks from the region where the ranges of ruficaudus and simulans converge, including a sample of 10 simulans from 42 km NE of Pierce (sample 5) and a sample of 7 ruficaudus from Lolo Pass (part of sample 6), scarcely 60 km apart in adjacent drainages. Despite the proximity of ruficaudus and simulans at these localities and their probable contact in the intervening Clearwater Mountains, we can find no definite evidence that the two forms intergrade in bacular morphology.

Other instances involving the juxtaposition of chipmunks with highly differentiated bacula have been interpreted as indicating reproductive isolation (e.g., Callahan, 1977 Callahan, , 1980 Patterson, 1984) . Detailed analyses at para patrie boundaries have shown that Eutamias townsendii and allies do not intergrade in characters of bacula (Sutton, in press; Williams, 1980) or call notes (Gannon, 1986) , despite apparent intergradation in cranial characters (Levenson and Hoffmann, 1984) . The same pattern holds true for Eutamias merriami and E. obscurus (Blankenship, 1985; Callahan, 1977) , which can be further distinguished by differential habitat selection (Blankenship and Brand, unpubl.) . On the basis of these more comprehensive studies, we are inclined to view ruficaudus and simulans as specifically distinct.

However, specific distinction of these forms must remain provisional because of the coarseness of our geographic analysis (Fig. 2) and our limited sample sizes. Bacular differences and variability (e.g., Table 1 ) suggest that our sample sizes are probably adequate for diagnosis (Le., characterizations of mean differences), but are clearly inadequate for estimating or comparing populational variability. Distinction of ruficaudus and simulans would also be better substantiated if distinctive differences between the forms could be shown in other character sets. Nonetheless, bacular differences can be indicative of specific differentiation, even if the species are similar enough in other characters to qualify as "cryptic" or "sibling" species. As is true in other animal groups, "Once discovered, and thoroughly studied, sibling species are usually found to have previously overlooked morphological differences" (Mayr, 1969:183) . We anticipate that future research will identify additional differences between ruficaudus and simu[ans, perhaps including biochemical and ecological characters. Although Levenson et al. (1985) reported no fixed allelic differences between ruficaudus and simulans, their samples represented a single bacular morph (Le., typical ruficaudus).

Patterns of character variation uncovered in our analysis parallel those reported in earlier analyses of chipmunks in general and Howell's (1929) Eutamias quadrivittatus species complex in particular (Patterson 1983 (Patterson , 1984 . Univariate analyses of variance show the baculum to be an especially useful taxonomic character, showing highly significant differences between species but relatively minor variations within them. Comparisons of population means within species either lack significance or else describe relatively little character variation, while comparisons between species are highly significant and descriptive (Table 1) . Comparable analyses of cranial characters show a different pattern of variation, one of extensive variation both between and within groups. Five of the 22 within-taxon comparisons tabulated in Table 3 are significant. Because of such geographic and nongeographic character variation, it is more difficult to describe and diagnose chipmunk taxa using mensural cranial characters. This accounts for the limited reliance that taxonomists customarily place on cranial characters in keys to chipmunk taxa (e.g .. Hall, 1981: 340-342; Howell, 1929,30-33) .

In several instances within the Eutamias quadrivittatus species complex, bacular differences indicative of reproductive isolation have been found to underlie cranial similarities that initially suggested intergradation. This was shown for Eutamias umbrinus and E. quadrivittatus by White (1953b;  see also Long and Cronkite, 1970) , for E. canipes and E. cinereicollis by Fleharty (960) , and for E. quadrivittatus and E. rufus by Patterson (1984) . It could be argued that, relative to cranial characters, the baculum is evolutionarily plastic, becoming "fixed" according to species in the absence of differentiation in other characters. However, Patterson (1980) showed Vol. 68, No.4 that chipmunks from the Organ Mountains of south-central New Mexico did not represent cinereicollis or canipes, as had been previously supposed, but instead represented a disjunct population of E. quadrivittatus. In this case, bacular morphology (corroborated by karyology) proved to be conservative compared to the external and cranial characters that caused this form to be confused with E. cinereicollis cinereU8 for 80 years. For this species complex and for other chipmunks (notably Howell's townsendii group; Callahan, 1977; Sutton and Nadler, 1974) , bacula appear to exhibit levels of within-group constancy and between-group variability that are useful for species diagnosis. For other chipmunks (e.g., members of the minimus group), in which the baculum is much smaller and possibly even vestigial, geographic variation of the baculum appears much more extensive and continuous (Sullivan, 1985) , and its value in diagnosing species limits may be correspondingly impaired.

Finally, we wish to note that the data presented here extend prior evidence of an unusual evolutionary feature of Neotamias chipmunks. The literature on mammalian systematics is replete with examples of hybrid zones, especially among rodents (see reviews by Barton and Hewitt, 1985; Moore, 1977) . According to prevailing paradigms, Neotamias might be expected to produce hybrid zones, being specifically diverse and exhibiting numerous situations of congeners in parapatry. However, no study of contact among species of Neotamias has yet identified a hybrid zone. Although more detailed field studies will be needed to document the lack of hybrids in this and other areas of parapatry, we believe the pattern will only become more conspicuous under scrutiny.

TABREF0.text: -Means (and SO) of eight bacular measurements for ten populations of Eutamias; Included in the table are F-tests of the equality of group means and their associated significance levels > 0.05); numbers below significant results are R2 values from analysis of variance. "Within taxon" tests compare five populations of simuians, then five populations of ruficaudus. "Between taxa" tests compare group means of simulans and ruficaudus.
